docs.lead_paragraph: President Bush will sign his long-promised tax cut today. But conservatives shouldn't break out the champagne just yet, nor should liberals start taking their antidepressants. Passing the cuts was easy. Mesmerized by projections of mountainous surpluses, few legislators could say no. But Congress and the president have turned their attention to crafting solutions to the nation's other problems, and now the real battle over taxes will begin. When the dust from this struggle settles, much of the relief the tax bill promises for later this decade is likely to be delayed, scaled back or repealed altogether.

headline.main: Don't Count on That Tax Cut

docs.abstract: Op-Ed article by Robert D Reischauer says Pres Bush will sign his long-promised tax cut, but conservatives should not rejoice and liberals should not despair because only now will real battle over taxes begin; says costs of tax cuts, new spending initiatives being considered and government's ongoing activities will strain available revenues; says politicians know it is easier to take away promised tax relief that has never been enjoyed than to raise actual taxes or cut existing programs; expects them to scale back or rescind 2004 and 2006 income tax cuts and reduce, but not eliminate, estate tax; recalls that Ronald Reagan's huge 1981 tax cut was rolled back about one-third by legislation passed in following three years; drawing (M)
docs.snippet: President Bush will sign his long-promised tax cut today. But conservatives shouldn't break out the champagne just yet, nor should liberals start taking their antidepressants.     Passing the cuts was easy. Mesmerized by projections of mountainous...

docs.lead_paragraph: Whether the work is paper cutouts, androgynous dancers or brightly colored portraits and windowscapes, Matisse's genius often speaks through deceptive simplicity. Yet in few cases is his minimalism more charged with effort and meaning than in his paintings and stained-glass windows for the Chapel of the Rosary in this medieval town near Nice. He was 81 when he completed the job. ''For all its imperfections,'' he wrote, ''I consider it my masterpiece.'' The austerity of the chapel is striking. A small modern building on the grounds of a residence of Dominican nuns, it displays three black-and-white murals -- ''The Way of the Cross,'' ''Virgin and Child'' and ''St. Dominic'' -- as well as three semi-abstract stained-glass windows. Matisse also designed the stone altar, a bronze cross, colorful vestments and the carved door to the confessional. The chapel can be visited as a museum, but it is above all the nuns' place of worship.

headline.main: Starting With the Secular, Ending Up With the Divine

docs.abstract: Alan Riding reviews exhibitions honoring Matisse's Chapel of the Rosary in Vence, France; one exhibition is at Musee Matisse in Nice, and the other is at Chateau de Villeneuve in Vence; drawing (M)
docs.snippet: Whether the work is paper cutouts, androgynous dancers or brightly colored portraits and windowscapes, Matisse's genius often speaks through deceptive simplicity. Yet in few cases is his minimalism more charged with effort and meaning than in his...

docs.lead_paragraph: Elsie Carter's morning routine never varies. She awakens at 6:30 to feed the cats, George and Sam, named for her friends, fellow AIDS patients who died. Then she butters a slice of toast and pours a tall tumbler of orange juice -- ''to put a little something in my stomach,'' Ms. Carter explains -- as she ingests the veritable pharmacy that keeps her alive. One by one, she picks her pills out of a crowded plastic box. They look pretty, like an assortment of colored gems. Ms. Carter, a recovering heroin addict who was so sick three years ago that she entered a hospice, says the medicines make her feel like ''I'm toxic.''

headline.main: In AIDS War, New Weapons and New Victims

docs.abstract: First article in series, AIDS at 20, examines changing face of epidemic; finds that AIDS in America can be survivable, thanks to so-called drug cocktails of antiviral medicines which have brought countless people back from brink of death; AIDS has killed more than 438,000 Americans and nearly 22 million people worldwide since 1981; it is no longer confined to gay men and intravenous drug abusers; in America, it is increasingly epidemic of the poor, which means increasingly minorities; blacks, who make up 13 percent of population, account for more than half of all new HIV infections; AIDS is leading case of death among blacks aged 25 to 44; disease still carries social stigma so strong that sometimes biggest burden of having HIV is keeping it secret; photos; charts; graph (L)
